courseTitle: Chemistry of Life: pH and Buffers

pageData.titleName2: Chemistry of Life: pH and Buffers

pageData.text: The regulation of pH is crucial in biological systems. <button class='glossary-text'>Buffers</button> occur naturally in body systems and help prevent dramatic shifts in pH. In this investigation, students will explore the concept of pH and the use of buffers to minimize fluctuations in pH. In the first activity, students examine buffer effectiveness at different pH levels. The second activity is an analysis of how the concentration of a buffer changes its effectiveness.

pageData.text: Often people think that muscle pain is caused by lactic acid. But maybe lactic acid isn’t all bad. The traditional thinking of lactic acid is that it is a “waste product” or “muscle poison” created when the cells don’t have enough oxygen, and built-up levels of it can cause muscle pain and fatigue. However, recent research has shown that lactic acid may not be the source of pain.

George Brooks has been studying lactic acid for over 40 years and thinks that more understanding of how cells use lactic acid could be useful for the treatment of a wide range of diseases. He discovered the “lactase shuttle” and described how lactic acid is produced all the time and more so during intense physical activity. Some cells produce it, and other cells require it for effective functioning. During exercise, the mitochondria preferentially use lactic acid instead of glucose or fatty acid for energy. When the brain uses lactic acid as a fuel source, the brain's executive function improves. Interestingly, after an injury, adrenaline activates the nervous system and triggers lactate production. Another interesting use of lactic acid is by tumor cells, which use it as an energy source. Dr. Brooks hopes that his research will help treat these patients by blocking the lactase shuttles between producer cells and tumor consumer cells<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1University of California - Berkeley. (2018, May 23). Rehabilitating lactate: From poison to cure: Once thought to cause muscle fatigue, it's now being investigated as a treatment for disease. ScienceDaily.
www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/05/180523145845.htm.

pageData.subTitle: pH
pageData.text: Aqueous solutions fall into one of three categories—<button class='glossary-text'>acidic</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>basic</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>neutral</button>—depending on the number of hydrogen ions (H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>) and hydroxide ions (OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>–</sup>) present. Water molecules constantly dissociate into H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> and OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>–</sup>, which then come back together to re-form water molecules. It should be noted that the H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> ion does not actually exist as such in an aqueous solution. Rather, H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> ions will associate with adjacent oxygen atoms, forming hydronium ions (H<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>O<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>). However, for the sake of convenience in our discussion of pH and <button class='glossary-text'>buffers</button>, we will refer to H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> rather than H<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>O<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>.

The ranges from 0 to 14. The neutral center of the scale, 7, represents the amount of H+ per liter of water at 25 °C, which is equal to 1 × 10–7 moles. Solutions with a pH of less than 7 possess more H+ and fewer OH– ions, and are considered acidic. Solutions with a pH greater than 7 possess less than 1 × 10–7 H+ (and therefore more OH–) and are considered basic, or alkaline. A solution with an equal number of H+ and OH– is considered neutral. Note that, because pH values are based upon logarithms of the base 10, each pH value varies from the next by a factor of 10 in terms of strength. For example, a solution with a pH of 5 is 10 times more acidic than one with a pH of 6.

pageData.subTitle: Logarithms and pH
pageData.text: It is useful to be able to determine the pH of an aqueous solution if the amount of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> is known; likewise, sometimes one knows the pH of the solution but needs to deduce the amount of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>. Brackets in an equation, such as [H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>] below, refer to the concentration.
To determine pH when [H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>] is known, use the following formula:
pH = -log[H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>]

For example: Determine the pH of an aqueous solution in which [H+] = 1 × 10–3 M.
pH = -log[H+] = -log(1 × 10–3) = 3
To determine [H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>] when the pH of a solution is known, use the same formula. The notation “inv log” refers to the inverse log.

For example: An aqueous solution has a pH of 5.5. Determine [H+] in M (moles/liter).
pH = -log[H+] = 5.5
log[H+] = -5.5
[H+] = inv log (-5.5) = 3.2 × 10-6 M

Humans must maintain a very narrow range of pH in the blood in order for enzymes to function properly. Human blood is normally maintained at the slightly <button class='glossary-text'>basic</button> (alkaline) level of 7.4. Death may result if the blood pH falls below 6.8 (resulting in acidosis) or rises above 7.8 (resulting in alkalosis). Imbalances in pH can occur when the body’s buffering systems do not function as they should.

pageData.subTitle: Buffers
pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>buffer</button> is a solution that resists change in pH upon addition of <button class='glossary-text'>acidic</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>basic</button> components. Thus, a solution can be buffered to prevent large shifts in pH upon the addition of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> or OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>. Typically, buffered solutions are composed of a weak acid and its conjugate base or a weak base and its conjugate acid.

Buffers occur naturally in biological systems. One well-studied buffering system in the bodies of mammals is the phosphate buffer system. The phosphate buffer system is present in intracellular and extracellular body fluids and regulates OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>–</sup> concentration in the kidneys. This system is composed of a weak acid, sodium diphosphate (NaH<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>PO<sub class='bodysubscript'>4</sub>), and its conjugate base, sodium monophosphate (Na<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>HPO<sub class='bodysubscript'>4</sub>). If a strong acid is added to the system, the acid reacts with sodium monophosphate (the weak base) to yield sodium diphosphate (the weak acid) and sodium chloride (NaCl, a salt). Similarly, if a strong base is added to the system, the base reacts with sodium diphosphate to yield sodium monophosphate and water.

Similar to the phosphate <button class='glossary-text'>buffer</button> system, the bicarbonate buffer system is an important homeostatic mechanism. The bicarbonate buffer system functions in the renal and respiratory systems and maintains pH in the blood and tissues and supports metabolic functions. The respiratory system controls acid levels through exhalation. This acid-base buffer system maintains the balance of carbonic acid (H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>), bicarbonate ion (HCO<sup class='bodySupscript'>–</sup><sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>), and carbon dioxide (CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>). Cellular respiration produces CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> as a waste product and is removed from the tissues by hydration to HCO<sup class='bodySupscript'>–</sup><sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>. Blood plasma transports HCO<sup class='bodySupscript'>–</sup><sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub> where it is dehydrated back to CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> , which is then released through exhaling (Figure 2).

It is useful to know how to prepare buffers to emulate those in natural systems. Cell and tissue culture techniques require the preparation and use of buffers to maintain conditions close to physiological osmolarity and pH. In order to select or prepare the ideal buffer for an experiment, one needs to know the optimal pH of the model system.

pageData.text: It is important to remember that acids and bases will dissociate in aqueous solutions. The <button class='glossary-text-underline'>acid dissociation constant (K<sub class='bodysubscript'>a</sub>)</button> is the equilibrium constant of the dissociation reaction of an acid in aqueous solution, representing a dynamic balance between the acid in its intact and dissociated states. Most <button class='glossary-text'>buffers</button> perform best at a pH near the <button class='glossary-text-underline'>pK<sub class='bodysubscript'>a</sub></button> (-log<sub class='bodysubscript'>10</sub> K<sub class='bodysubscript'>a</sub>, a logarithmic representation of the acid dissociation constant) of the acid used for their preparation. When designing a buffer, the chemicals used should have pK<sub class='bodysubscript'>a</sub>s that are close to the target pH.

pageData.subTitle: The Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation
pageData.text: The pH of a buffered solution can be calculated using the :pH = pKa + log ([conjugate base]/[acid])
For example, suppose a buffer is prepared by combining 1.0 M acetic acid (C2H4O2) and 1.0 M NaOH. The pKa of acetic acid is 4.78. What would the pH of this solution be?
pH = pK<sub class='bodysubscript'>a</sub> + log ([conjugate base]/[acid]) = 4.78 + log (1.0/1.0) = 4.78

The of a solution indicates the amount of H+ or OH- the buffer is able to absorb without a significant change in pH. The buffering capacity of a solution is determined by the amounts of acid and conjugate base it contains; therefore, increasing the quantity of each will increase the buffering capacity. However, the ratio of the acid and base must be kept constant in order to maintain the desired pH. Maximum buffering capacity is reached when pH = pKa, and the useful is approximately pKa ± 1. Beyond the buffering range, the buffering agent will be largely unable to resist changes in pH.

Match the color of the solution in the first well to the Bogen’s Universal Indicator Color Chart to determine the pH, and record this pH in Data Table 1. The first well of each row will be used for later color comparisons; don’t add anything else to these wells.

Note: Bogen’s Universal Indicator is designed for testing solutions with pH in the range 4–10. Any reading of pH 4 should be recorded as ≤ pH 4. Likewise, any reading of pH 10 should be recorded as ≥ pH 10. If the color of the solution falls between two color standards, e.g., between pH 7 and pH 8, record it as pH 7.5.

In the second well of each row (i.e., column 2), add one drop of 0.1 M HCl using the designated dropper pipet. Gently swirl the solutions while resting the tray on the table. Record the resulting pH of each solution in Data Table 1.

data.title: Acid dissociation constant (K<sub class='bodysubscript'>a</sub>)
data.content: The equilibrium constant of the dissociation reaction of an acid in aqueous solution; it represents a dynamic balance between the acid in its intact and dissociated states

data.title: Acidic
data.content: Describes solutions with a pH of less than 7 and that possess more than 1 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>-7</sup> H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>

data.title: Basic
data.content: Describes solutions with a pH greater than 7 and that possess less than 1 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>-7</sup> H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>

data.title: Buffer
data.content: A substsance that prevents dramatic changes in the pH of a solution

data.title: Buffering capacity
data.content: Indicates the amount of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> or OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup> the buffer is able to absorb without a significant change in pH

data.title: Buffering range
data.content: The range over which a buffer can maintain a more or less constant pH

data.title: Dilute
data.content: To make weaker by the addition of water or another solvent

data.title: Neutral
data.content: Describes a pH of 7, which represents 1 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>-7</sup> moles of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> per liter of water at 25 °C

data.title: pH scale
data.content: A measurement of the acidity or basicity of aqueous or other liquid solutions

data.title: pK<sub class='bodysubscript'>a</sub>
data.content: -log10 K<sub class='bodysubscript'>a</sub>; a logarithmic representation of the acid dissociation constant
